federal court rules 1979 (cth), o. 4, r. 14. held: (per smithers and keely jj., sweeney j. not deciding) o. 4, r. 14(2) which relevantly provides that a corporation may not without the leave of the court commence or carry on any proceeding otherwise than by a solicitor, confers a discretion upon the court to grant leave, which discretion will be exercised in favour of a company where there is sufficient reason. (2) (per smithers and keely jj., sweeney j. not deciding.) where a refusal to grant leave would leave the company unable to continue its proceedings, the loss of skilled legal assistance to the court should be a factor which carries no weight in the exercise of the discretion. adam p. brown male fashions pty ltd v. philip morris incorporated (1981) 148 clr 170 mcgrath v. dobie [1890] viclawrp 133 ; (1890) 16 vlr 646 ; o'toole v. scott (1965) ac 939 ; hubbard association of scientologists international v. anderson [1972] vicrp 37 ; (1972) vr 340 ; tritonia ltd v. equity and law life assurance society (1943) ac 584 ; frinton and walton urban district council v. walton and district sand and mineral co. ltd (1938) 1 all er 649 ; london county council and london tramways co. (1897) 13 tlr 254 ; scriven v. jescott (leeds) ltd (1908) 53 sol. j. 101; federated engine-drivers' and firemen's association of australasia v. broken hill proprietary co. ltd [1913] hca 71 ; (1913) 16 clr 245 ; house v. the king [1936] hca 40 ; (1936) 55 clr 499. 4

citances.sentence: Fourth, any liberality in approach the Court might be inclined to adopt where leave is sought by a respondent (and therefore not the moving party in the litigation) is not relevant in this proceeding (contrast Super Choice Now Pty Ltd v BrisConnections Management Company Ltd [2009] FCA 1026 at [19] and Tobacco Control Coalition Inc v Philip Morris (Australia) Ltd [2000] FCA 131 at [5] ).
